headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Tonight: Doug Emhoff, Barack Obama, Michelle Obama To Address DNC; Tony Goldwyn's New Film "Ezra" Explores The Challenges Of Raising Children With Autism; Warriors Coach Fires Up DNC Crown, Takes Shot At Trump. Aired 12:30-1p ET

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: That was a few rising stars in the Democratic Party drawing a contrast between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump. Joining me now to chat about day one and what is going to happen day two, three, and four, here at the DNC, co-hosts of the Pivot podcast, Kara Swisher and Scott Galloway.How excited am I?

utterances.speaker: KARA SWISHER, CNN CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Are you?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Are you kidding?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: We're influencers, you know.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I'm influenced by you.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You've influenced me. Both of you.SCOTT GALLOWAY, CO-HOST, "PIVOT": Yes, that's literally the worst title in the world.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. So what do you want to be called?

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Irritating (ph).

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Master of the universe.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: No, podcasters, irritants.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Masters of the universe. No, no, irritants are not good. OK, so let's talk, you were here, just your broad takeaways.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Well, it was exciting. It was, you know, interesting. I interviewed David Axelrod this morning, who's on CNN. And one of the things I agreed with him was it's discordant. They were trying to sort of move Biden along. And at the same time, talk about Kamala Harris and who she is. And I think it should all be about her, because it's shifted from the Biden conference to that.And so they were having a little hard time doing that. And then at the same time attacking Trump a lot, but it was good. It was exciting. It was fun. And some of the speeches like you just showed were amazing.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. What do you think, Scott?

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: I think it's mostly about the perception. It's made for TV. The energy is amazing. The visuals are great. A lot of really emotional moments, kind of the beginning of the long goodbye for Biden. But I think the energy and the vibe, if this is kind of the vibe election, the vibe was very strong last night.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Although it was a short goodbye. It's going to be a -- you're not going to hear about Biden again, I think.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, I was just thinking, you know, it's true about the first night, but now they have three more nights.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's obviously going to be very focused on Kamala Harris and on Tim Walz and the contrast with Donald Trump. You talked about the sort of marketing, the made for TV.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I mean, it did used to be, before the three of us were born, that they actually did real business in these halls.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That's -- this is where they decided who the nominee was. Now it is all about marketing. Assess their marketing so far and their campaign.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I thought the AOC did that. And, you know, it's the idea here is Scott says not everyone's watching it on television. They're watching it in pieces. And so you have to see -- and not just those viral moments that are exciting. It's what's the messaging.I thought AOC did the best job. She's just a perfect candidate for that age because she was talking about the economy in a different way and also attacking Trump.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: They're talking about being a waitress and not having any --

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: But you could see how she constructed it. It was so snackable, like how she did --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: -- the different pieces and I could see where the cuts were and she knew them without knowing them.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: She is --

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: She didn't know them.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: She is an incredible communicator.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But there are -- they did try to construct this convention for the modern age of influencers.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I know whatever we're going to call them Gen Z. They invited a lot of them here. There was a brief speaking slot for one or two of them earlier. I mean if they were to say Scott Galloway, how do I reach the not only those voters, but the message that the voters want to hear, what would your tagline be? What would your 32nd might be? GALLOWAYThey're trying to figure out a series of moments. There was some really nice ones yesterday with AOC. I thought the most powerful moment in the entire, yes, convention so far was the young woman from Kentucky talking about the importance of bodily autonomy. That was very --

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: That was striking.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that was a moment where I think a lot of the nation just kind of stood still. So, and those moments are incredibly snackable and you can see the production of the people other than these things going on too long. There are a series of moments. We're going to see last night over and over in small snack size consumable bits for the next week.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: I thought the best moment actually was Kamala Harris coming out for that little --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: -- surprise speech. And it was short, it was sweet --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: -- it was focused.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: And I thought that was great.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I want to play Hillary Clinton. And a moment that was -- I was on the edge of my chair, I don't know if you were, when she was speaking and the crowd started chanting, "lock him up."

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Wasn't sure if she was going to shut it down. She did not.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: She did not.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Let's watch.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) HILLARY CLINTON, 2016 DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: He made his own kind of history. The first person to run for president with 34 felony convictions. As vice president, as vice president, Kamala sat in the situation room. (CHANTING) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I don't think I've ever seen her enjoy a moment as much as that moment, Kara.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know what? Let's give it to her because she deserves it, kind of thing. At the same time, this was a goodbye to Hillary, too, right? It's a goodbye, it's a closing chapter on Biden, closing chapter on Hillary, and closing chapter on Trump. And that's what Kamala has to do here.Even though she's the incumbent, she doesn't feel like the incumbent. And Trump feels like the incumbent. So that's what, you know, let her have that. I -- it's not tasteful, but you know, she's put up with a lot, so.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Let me talk about men and about masculinity, which you talk about a lot, Scott.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: He's a man, by the way.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You are.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Thanks for that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: She's full of compliments.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes, there we go.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Or maybe you're a trained observer. The question about how Kamala Harris in particular is going to reach some of the men, particularly white men --

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- particularly white working class men, or even young men, Gen Z --

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- men who are gravitating Towards Trump and towards --

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- Republicanism because of everything that they've done online.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What does she need to do to get them back and are you seeing it here or seeing it in the program to come?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: It's protector. It's the protector which you talk a lot. And she had that word, I'm the protector, too. And that's -- that is appealing. It's the -- you know, people joke about he's sort of the dad, you know, the dad jokes, which I spent a lot of time listening to. But there is appeal to that, to young men.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Well, a candidate who can fix your car.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Right?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, anybody who could fix my car, that would be good.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: I can fix your car.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Really? OK, we'll talk.Kara Swisher, Scott Galloway, so good to see you. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much, Dana.

utterances.speaker: GALLOWAY
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much, Dana.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The stars are aligning in Chicago this week as Hollywood mobilizes behind Kamala Harris. My guest now may have played a Republican president on TV, but last night he took on a different role as the emcee on night one of the Democratic convention. Here with me now is actor and director Tony Goldwyn.Thank you so much for being here.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Dana, so happy to be here.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What made you want to be so involved in this event?

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Well, I was honored to be asked, and this is an incredibly important election, and we find ourselves surprisingly in the past month in this sort of sea change in the American political culture. So, you know, I want to do everything I can to help tell Kamala Harris's story and do what I can to kind of, you know, help present that to the American people because a lot of people know about Kamala, but they don't really know Kamala, so.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What should they know?

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Well, she has spent her entire career in public service motivated, you know, driven first by getting into going to law school because her close friend had been sexually assaulted and that was a profound motivator for her.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And you've been active, I'm sorry to interrupt, you've been active in criminal justice issues for some time.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Yes, criminal justice reform has always, you know, been, you know, on the board of the Innocence Project, which is sort of the foremost organization in the country promoting innocence, but also, you know, promoting to prevent innocent people from being put in jail in the first place. So, yes, it's an arena that's familiar to me.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You were way back a month ago when President Biden was still running, you and other actors who played presidents did kind of an online video for President Biden, and I wonder what your thoughts are. You mentioned that there's kind of a new energy.Your thoughts are about the transition, and I assume you thought it was the right thing to do, but given the fact that you were clearly all in for President Biden, the change.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, for me, you know, I think people's -- I sense a lot of amnesia about where we were in the fall of, you know, November of 2019 and the winter of 2020 and, you know, in the catastrophe that was COVID and the chaos and the shocking reality of January 6th and, you know, an economy that was in free fall and, you know, people saying it was the next depression.And I really, you know, it seems clear to me that President Biden through sort of calm, steady leadership pulled us out of that and the, you know, NATO was fractured and he did a lot of just incredible quiet work that he does not get credit for. So -- and then, you know, with the Supreme Court that Trump appointed, we now have the reality of the Dobbs decision and, you know, a third of American women living under an abortion ban, so I felt I had to get involved. And you know, we did that funny little bit, you know, TV movie precedents before his State of the Union speech, and at that point he killed it. You know, he had an incredible State of the Union, but, you know, that first debate was incredibly rough. And, you know, the realities of being 83 years old, you know, we're working against him, and I thought he made an incredibly courageous and must have been a very painful decision. But it suddenly, you know, through, you know, quite a selfless act, he has shifted the tide. And by acting so fast and the Democratic Party so quickly coming around to Kamala.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Well, this was a film that came out at the end of May, and it's still in theaters, but now --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: -- on on-demand. "Ezra's" was inspired by the screenwriter who's my oldest friend in the world. I've known him for 43 years. We've been best friends. He has an autistic son, and is a wonderful screenwriter, but wanted to write a film inspired by his story. So it's really about three generations, you know, Robert De Niro and Bobby Cannavale and Rose Byrne play the grandfather, father, and mother of this 11-year-old autistic boy.And, you know, they're struggling to figure out parenthood. And it's -- we were -- it was a beautiful experience. And --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And you can get it on -- it was in theaters. You can watch it on-demand now.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. I really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: So good to see you.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Nice to see you.

utterances.speaker: GOLDWYN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Tim Walz isn't the only coach firing up the crowd here at the DNC. Golden State Warriors coach Steve Kerr, who played right here as a star of the Michael Jordan era, Chicago Bulls in the 1990s, gave quite a pep talk last night. Just nine days after coaching Team USA to thrilling Olympic victory, Kerr invoked his star player's iconic moment after the clutch three pointer that guaranteed the team's gold medal as a metaphor for November 5th.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) STEVE KERR, GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS & TEAM USA COACH: After the results are tallied that night, we can, in the words of the great Steph Curry, we can tell Donald Trump, night, night. Thank you (CHEERING) (END VIDEO CLIP)
